comments.title: Format
comments.content: Expertly formatted!

comments.title: Font
comments.content: Make sure you're using the correct font and size 12.

comments.title: Identification
comments.content: You need to put your name, class, and name of the assignment at the top of the first page.

comments.title: Paragraphs
comments.content: Please note that new paragraphs need to be indented (set off) 1 cm from the left-hand margin.

comments.title: Spacing
comments.content: Please make sure that you're using 1,5 line spacing.

comments.title: Titles
comments.content: For the title of a book, play, or film, use underlining or italics. For short stories, poems, and individual articles, use quotation marks. E.g.: _Macbeth_ but "Sonnet 18".

comments.title: Grammar
comments.content: Well done! The grammar works fine here in general.

comments.title: Articles
comments.content: An article should be used here. Check whether it should be definite (the) or indefinite (a/an).

comments.title: Article Remove
comments.content: No definite article should be used here. Check the rules for article use with uncountables and generals. E.g. "Modern British literature" (not "The modern British literature").

comments.title: Article Wrong Form
comments.content: Wrong form of indefinite article. "a" is used before consonant sounds; "an" is used before vowel sounds.

comments.title: Dangling Phrase
comments.content: This is a dangling participle/phrase, i.e. it modifies an element of the sentence other than the one it was intended to modify. Please rephrase to avoid confusion. E.g. "Gliding down the sky at awe-inspiring speed, we watched the fighter jet" - clearly the intention here is that the jet is gliding down the sky, but the subject of the complete clause is "we", so the sentence ends up meaning that we glided down the sky as we watched the jet; a rephrasing is needed.

comments.title: Fragment
comments.content: Fragment/incomplete sentence. These words alone cannot form a complete sentence. A proper sentence needs a subject and a verb phrase.

comments.title: It/There
comments.content: Check the rules for using "it" and "there" in English, corresponding to Swedish "det". E.g. "It is raining"; "There is time left for this".

comments.title: It's/Its
comments.content: Please note the difference between "it's" (the contraction of 'it is') and "its" (the possessive form of 'it').

comments.title: Who's/Whose
comments.content: Please note that "who's" is short for "who is" and "whose" is a possessive that permits the reference to things and/or people.

comments.title: Prepositions
comments.content: Your use of preposition(s) here is not idiomatic. Note that English has its own system of preposition usage.

comments.title: Pronouns
comments.content: Unclear use of pronoun(s) here. Please make sure that the pronoun is referring to the right noun and that the reference (or antecedent) is clear. E.g. "She fixed her brother's coat, and then handed it back to him."

comments.title: Run-onsentence
comments.content: Makesuretostructureyoursentencesproperly.Separateclausesneedtobejoinedusingconjunctionsandseparatedusingcommas;orsemi-colons;orfullstops.E.g."I hate jazz, it's so unstructured" - here we have a comma splice, which may be fixed thus: "I hate jazz, because it's so unstructured".

comments.title: Sentence Structure
comments.content: This sentence structure does not work. Please rephrase.

comments.title: Verbs
comments.content: This verb needs to be followed by a gerund (ing-form) here. E.g. "I hate speed-dating"; "The phone stopped ringing".

comments.title: Verbs Irregular
comments.content: This is an irregular verb. Use the correct form. E.g., "teach" > "taught".

comments.title: Verbs Tense
comments.content: Check your use of verb tenses and that your choices are consistent. Use auxiliary verbs that communicate tense where needed. E.g. "We had been eating for a while, when Tom suddenly arrived".

comments.title: Verbs Subject/Verb
comments.content: Note the subject/verb agreement here. A single subject needs a single verb, and a plural subject needs a plural verb. Note that the main noun is not always the one closest to the verb. E.g. "The problem of stray cats in our streets is increasing" (not "are").

comments.title: Verbs Use Infinitive
comments.content: This verb needs to be followed by an infinitive here. E.g. "I would love to do that"; "I hate to bring this up, but"; "We stopped to get gas".

comments.title: Word Order
comments.content: The word order here is wrong. Reorder.

comments.title: Adjective or adverb
comments.content: An adjective describes a noun. An adverb describes a verb, an adjective or another adverb. E.g. He is quick - He runs quickly.

comments.title: Verbs Preposition
comments.content: After prepositions, verbs use progressive form ("-ing"). E.g., "We are talking about going to the party", "Compared to partying, school is kind of boring".

comments.title: Punctuation
comments.content: Nicely done! Punctuation works fine here in general.

comments.title: Apostrophe
comments.content: Incorrect use of apostrophe. Apostrophes are used to show possession and to form contractions. E.g. "Linda's dog"; "I'm at the dentist's"; "It's nice to be here"; "We haven't seen him today"

comments.title: CapitalLetters
comments.content:
Checkyouruseofcapitallettershere.Notethatcapitalizationisusedinallwordsoftitlesandheadings,
		exceptnon-initialarticlesandprepositions.E.g._TheMillontheFloss_.

comments.title: Citation
comments.content:
Ifyouusewordsfromanothertextdirectly,
		youneedtoputthemwithinquotationmarks.

comments.title: PunctuationColon
comments.content: Acolonshouldbeusedhere.

comments.title: Comma
comments.content: Acommashouldnotbeusedhere.

comments.title: CommaClauses/Phrases
comments.content:
Usecommasonbothsidesofnon-essentialphrases/clauses,
		suchasnon-definingrelativeclauses.E.g."My uncle, who by the way is a farmer, does not like cows."

comments.title: CommaEnumeration
comments.content: Useacommaandconjunction(suchas"and" or "or") before the last item in an enumeration. E.g. "I like trains, boats, and planes.", "Should we go to the cinema, the theatre, or the opera house?"

comments.title: CommaIntroductoryPhrase
comments.content: Useacommatosettheintroductoryphrase(adverbial)off.E.g."However, this is not a major problem." Always use a comma after an opening prepositional phrase. E.g. "To be a great dancer, you must work on your moves every day."

comments.title: Exclamation
comments.content:
Useexclamationpoints(!)toemphasizeaparticularpointoranoutburstindialogue,
		butusesparinglyotherwise.Informalwriting,
		donotuseexclamations!

comments.title: HyphenRedundant
comments.content: Ahyphenshouldnotbeusedhere.

comments.title: HyphenWordsWorkingTogether
comments.content: Useahyphentoconnecttwowordsworkingtogetherasacompoundadjective.E.g."A four-leaf clover"; "Twentieth-century literature".

comments.title: Period
comments.content: Use a period (full stop) here.

comments.title: Structure
comments.content: Nicely done! Effectively structured and argued in general.

comments.title: Structure Argumentation Logic
comments.content: Confusing/contradictory/illogical. Please check the overall logic of the point you’re trying to make here, and make sure to phrase your point clearly.

comments.title: Argumentation Support
comments.content: To make this clear and more convincing, you need to support and further explain the argument here.

comments.title: Argumentation False Conclusion
comments.content: This conclusion does not seem to follow from the argument.

comments.title: Argumentation Conclusion Clarify
comments.content: This conclusion needs further elaboration/clarification.

comments.title: Argumentation Introduction
comments.content: Use a pointed question, a description, or maybe a surprising opening statement, to make the introduction more effective.

comments.title: Structure Argumentation Implicitly Clear
comments.content: Your point here is implicitly clear, but needs to be made more explicit.

comments.title: Argumentation Thesis Earlier
comments.content: Your thesis needs to be presented earlier in the text.

comments.title: Argumentation Thesis Unclear
comments.content: Your thesis needs to be clearer.

comments.title: Cohesion
comments.content: "This/that/these/those" should be followed with a specific noun, for clarity. Eg. "We need to take care of this problem."

comments.title: CohesionEnumeration
comments.content: Makesurethatifyoustartanenumerationitiscontinued.Ifyouwrite"First...", there should come a "Second..." later in the text. Also, in an enumeration, openings need to be parallel. E.g. First - Second - Last, or Firstly - Secondly - Lastly.

comments.title: Cohesion Pronouns
comments.content: Make sure it is clear what pronouns such as "it" and "this" refer back to.

comments.title: Cohesion Open Paragraph
comments.content: Open each paragraph with a clear topic sentence that indicates what central idea the paragraph is about.

comments.title: Cohesion Irrelevant Passage
comments.content: This passage does not seem clearly relevant to your main focus here.

comments.title: Cohesion Passage Order
comments.content: This passage seems to belong elsewhere in your text - rethink the order!

comments.title: Cohesion Opening Phrases
comments.content: You need to use more adverbial opening phrases to tie your sentences and/or paragraphs together. E.g. ?However?, ?Moreover?, ?Besides?.

comments.title: Paragraphs
comments.content: You need to break the paragraph and begin a new one here.

comments.title: Style
comments.content: Nicely done! Appropriate register in general.

comments.title: Quotations
comments.content: Quotations need to be introduced properly, and cannot be put as separate sentences. E.g. "As Bill Smith notes, 'it is crucial to cite sources correctly if one wishes to be taken seriously'."

comments.title: OveruseAderbialOpenings
comments.content:
Pleasemakesurethatyou'renotoverusingadverbialopeningssuchas,
		forexample,
		"Besides" and "Finally".

comments.title: Overuse Words/Terms
comments.content: Check to see if you're overusing or repeating this. Please use synonyms to attain variation and precision.

comments.title: Redundant
comments.content: This phrase is redundant; it makes your sentence longer than it has to be. Remember the word limit, and make each word count!

comments.title: Register
comments.content: You're using the wrong register here. Use words or phrases that reflect the intended style and tone of this text to avoid being either too informal or too formal. (If applicable, make sure that you've read the instructions for this assignment closely.)

comments.title: Variation
comments.content: Be sure to vary sentence construction, by for example shortening, combining, or dividing the sentence(s), to make your text more effective.

comments.title: Contractions
comments.content: Avoid contractions in formal writing. E.g., "isn't" > "is not", "he's" > "he is".

comments.title: Exclamations
comments.content: Avoid exclamations in formal writing.

comments.title: Word usage
comments.content: Nicely done! Vocabulary and spelling are effective in general.

comments.title: Missing word(s)
comments.content: At least one word is missing here.

comments.title: False Friend
comments.content: Some words in English are similar to words in Swedish, but do not mean the same thing. Use a dictionary!

comments.title: Spelling
comments.content: Check spelling and correct throughout the text. Make sure to get rid of homonym errors; homonyms are words that sound the same, but have different meaning. E.g. "their/there"; "son/sun".

comments.title: Spelling American/British
comments.content: Use American or British spelling consistently. E.g. "color" vs. "colour".

comments.title: Incorrect
comments.content: Word(s) or idiom is not used correctly here. Use a dictionary!

comments.title: Hyphenate
comments.content: These two words need to be hyphenated, since they modify a noun. E.g., "a six-foot tree", "twentieth-century literature".

comments.title: Word Form
comments.content: You use the wrong form of a word. E.g. noun: imagination, verb: imagine, adjective: imaginative. Use a dictionary!
